everything else remains true:

you need people to do big things
you need people to go further
you need people to give shape and texture to your existence

and it would be really stupid for you to construe what i'm saying as advice, and even stupider to try to apply it.

it is not something that can be prescribed and bought wholesale over the counter.
also, don't make the mistake of thinking the constraints are financial. all the real constraints are psychological, and there's no dearth of super-rich and super-enslaved people.

outside of a few rare cases, everyone is just trying to domesticate each other into being a good boy. what's good changes with the times and the bubbles you inhabit, but everyone around you is trying to force you to be a kind of person

happy to say that i'm relatively quite unconstrained by this network of relationships because i never built it for the same reason. and i've made my peace with the tradeoffs.

i'm unconstrained in ways most people will never experience, because they don't have the necessary dna (hear stupidity) needed to do this, and they will never be able to make those trade-offs.

by all accounts, my life will be a lot more insipid and colorless than most people in general, and it'll be okay because that's my cross to bear in this life and there's nothing i can do to change it.

"but doesn't being unconstrained mean living a more colorful life?"

well, it would, provided i had the ability to desire it. i don't. when the constraints go, the desires also go along with them.

for example, this was my day today

multiple short workouts per day work much better for me now versus one single large workout and then staying sedentary for the rest of the day.

i'm anyway not training for performance or optimizing for one single metric. the only thing i'm optimizing for is maintaining a decent level of fitness and strength so i never have to complain about "adulting"

good sunlight is the same reason i could never get myself to install mosquito nets. for my work room, a mosquito racket still remains my preferred solution. mosquitoes have a tendency to rest in dark spaces and black material. if you make it a point to disturb and kill them once in the morning and once in the evening, just after sunset, it will help alleviate the issue

i work from my study+workout room and only enter my bedroom at night to sleep. it has taken care of the mosquito problem entirely. as my bedroom stays closed the entire day, i no longer have mosquitoes pestering me during sleep. i recommend everyone try this.

having a separate work room and bedroom has many other benefits as well. won't elaborate right now. plus a lot of it has to do with my own idiosyncrasies and preferences that won't easily generalise.

but another thing i can recommend is having your workout gear in your work room. it makes you work our more and frequently. it keeps you moving.

(i have six kettlebells, a trx suspension trainer, an 8kg indian club, and a stationary bike. advice may not work for more. elaborate setups with power racks and barbells.)

i have been in this house for nearly 3 years now, and it has been nothing short of a fantastic experiment with many learnings which i will carry with me for the rest of my life.

in general, any such playground that allows you lots of trial and error teaches you about systems, good design, user psychology, and boosts your foresight for what will work and what won't.

i have learned so much about my own behavior and designing a space that works for me. always learning something new with every change.

a lot of it is wasteful, but once in a while, you come upon something that really sticks and improves your quality of life dramatically in the long term. all the wasted time, effort, and money in iteration is worth it.

@BoldTrashBandit @paraschopra i work from my study+workout room and yes, only enter my bedroom at night to sleep. it has taken care of the mosquito problem entirely. as my bedroom stays closed the entire day, i no longer have mosquitoes pestering me during sleep. i recommend everyone try this.

identity is always accumulating; the truthseeker is always shedding. this is very easy to do. you only need to be in touch with your real intent at all times.

objective knowledge, or the lack of it, is quite secondary. it is necessary, but it is secondary. intent is where identity does most of its damage. it obscures it, weaves stories around it.

if i refuse to acknowledge my intent, all the knowledge i seek will be cherrypicked to add to my lies.

@MangoZeus a man who is always in touch with his real intent will gradually have to drop all labels. because he will soon find that his real intent is rarely aligned with any label in the long term; it only happens to be aligned situationally, and only as a coincidence.

if my identity is indian and my real intent/incentive has got nothing to do with india or the welfare of the state but towards promoting my own selfish motives, i will conjure up lies to conclude why my actions are aligned with the welfare of the state. but in truth, they aren't; they're only aligned with my own personal welfare.

a man seeking truth in this case will see that his intent is selfish and will have to drop his indian identity if he wishes to reason truthfully.

not at all. identity obscures genuine intent and incentive, that's all. for truth, an honest acknowledgement of intent is primary, and that's where identity butts in all the time. if a man is cognizant of how his real intent goes against his own public identity/mask/persona/narrative and still chooses to acknowledge his real intent and incentives and reasons from there, he's aligned with the truth. 

an honest acknowledgement of intent is the simplest thing. nothing complicated about it.
@MangoZeus thinking of 'when' as an event leads to confusion. the 'when' is a present continuous state, not a future perfect state

the influence of identity is always active. truthseeking exists regardless of identity and is breaking its illusions constantly. there's no final moment as such, it's a never-ending process. 

the 'when' in "when the truth is evident" is not an event, but a constant state of observation and enquiry.
@MangoZeus but what you're describing is people choosing parties because identity (falseness). so how does it contradict voltaire
@MangoZeus i don't think he meant truth as one particular thing. my interpretation of it is that you can either be constantly in touch with what's true in any situation or be partisan

your manager does not have to be your therapist (and i do not hold the latter in high regard, either) but how can you expect to coach another human and help them perform better by ignoring 90% of their life?

unless you think coaching is not a part of your job, and you look at humans like useful tools you buy from the market to be used and disposed off later.

if you have a mercantile nature, it's easy to forget that you're dealing with a human who, just like you, is an extremely complex being, with a whole life you aren't privy to.

if they're going through a rough time in their personal life, of course it will reflect in their professional life. and as a manager, if you don't even acknowledge it, no employee will want to work with you again.

if having more compassion for my team came at the expense of going a little bit slower and being a little less professional and a little more human, i would make that trade-off in a heartbeat.

effectiveness and cut-throatism are only great when they're one's natural disposition. they can't be thrust on others who do not have that disposition.

i've always found well-meaning professional advice like

"never bring your whole self to work, only your work self"

"your manager is not your therapist"

"compartmentalize"

to be utterly misanthropic and violent in its modality.

this is most easily witnessed in the individual, rather than groups, which, by definition, operate on consensus. once you start to see reality as it is, you will never enjoy the comforts of association henceforth and will be a pariah everywhere
"when the truth is evident, it is impossible for parties and factions to arise" ‚Äî voltaire

we are a largely very inconsiderate folk, with little to no empathy or consideration for one another, with a lot of division and internal conflict due to language, caste, culture, and just overarching scarcity.

there's no *one problem* to which *one panacea* exists. everything plays into everything else.

if i were to summarize it in one statement, i'd say, 

india is far, far away from a free market. too much explicit and implicit friction in everything.

unwrap this and you'll open up a pandora's box of issues ‚Äî most of which aren't solvable without a collective effort. if somehow, 90% of the population woke up one day and decided to be cooperators instead of defectors, a lot of systems would break and it would lead to total chaos. 

a lot of what works in this country is contingent on defection and corruption.

an almost magical transformation has to sweep over the entire nation's conscience that suddenly makes us all a lot more considerate, and blesses us with the aesthetic and civic sensibility that's essential to a good moral education. till such a thing happens, the good individuals will always find it easier to flock to greener pastures.

it's a massive coordination problem rooted in very simple game theory.

i can be bullish on indians the same way i can be bullish on singaporeans or the vietnamese. you can always be bullish on the individual.

but ask me to be bullish on india, and now we are speaking about something else entirely.

the only construct that actually exists is the legal system. and the fuzziness of society ultimately reifies itself in the law. the law is the hard constraint on reality in many of these cases. so till we have an evolving legal system in place, what you're saying already exists.

and i for one wouldn't like to add more shoulds than those mandated by the law. the law is as conservative i get, and no more.

*everything* you do has a certain cost that's being paid by others. but a defining element of society is the set of acts it doesn't rationalize the costs to, because they're too obscure and non-obvious to attract attention. only individuals who study the society within them are able to even recognize these costs.

what would i do if i had the misfortune of bearing a child who was born with a bloodlust and had extremely malevolent tendencies?

i don't know.

i don't know what to do even with normal children, except helping them understand reality better. that's all you can do for anyone.

saying all this is pretty easy. but dealing personally with a loved one with the kind of preferences that would have them jailed and damned if they were to ever exercise them is a gnarly problem. in truth, shaming remains the most convenient and effective recourse in most cases.

but i would chalk that up to my ignorance and wisdom in dealing with the situation more than anything else.

we are all ultimately quite ignorant when it comes to dealing with anyone even slightly off center.

"grow up" and "don't be a fucking retard" are how conservatives have always dealt with the problem ‚Äî by shaming people into submission.

and if your only goal is to help people conform to society, shaming abnormal individuals works in most cases.

but once that individual finds a community, that stops working. you can't shame a collective; it backfires.

but you can shame individuals with no moral support.

in any case, do you think shaming anyone into submission is the long-term correct approach? i do not think so.

there are more kinks in this world than you can think of. civilized society creates this illusion of normalcy, but the tail is longer than what you and i can imagine, and it is thoroughly repressed in the majority of people.

all "abnormal" people, especially the ones abnormal in morally reprehensible ways, have all of my sympathy.

but i'm sorry bro, you live in a society that imposes huge penalties on what you wish to do.

the only way you could help someone like this, ‚Äî or anyone at all, for that matter ‚Äî is by helping them understand reality better, which would help them honestly evaluate all the trade-offs they'll be making.

if i wish to fuck a toaster then i wish to fuck a toaster. it is what it is.

you can replace the word 'toaster' with something that would immediately make the preference a lot more reprehensible, like 'child', and it still wouldn't change the fact.

the problem is not with the fact, but what happens when a bunch of people create a community around the fact. they start coming up with the most fantastical defenses to defend their preferences.

the defending is the problem, not the wish or preference. because it's a bunch of lies. and you WILL fuck up your life because these fantastical justifications will mess with your understanding of the real trade-offs involved with your preferences.

one has the right to have any preference under the sun, but they will be subject to the trade-offs that come with exercising those preferences.

an individual with no moral support from anywhere would probably fare better in dealing with this situation than a community, where he would find a bunch of cheerleaders who would lead him away from the truth.

humans are way more diverse and weird than society would have you believe. not only are we living beings, we operate on the memetic plane and not merely on a biological one, which makes us orders of magnitude more diverse than any other species we know of.

unless you understand what you're individually dealing with, you will be led astray by a community that seeks home in consensus and not truth.

this is the problem with most leftist extremist ideology today. it is honest in its revelation of the facts, but utterly dishonest in its synthesis and integration with the larger context it inhabits.

it has no estimation of trade-offs, and passes laws and decrees that have no bearing to how reality works.

i get a lot of questions about addiction, and how to get rid of addictions. i also get a lot of questions about what i feel is the spiritual inverse of an addiction, where someone who really doesn't want to do something that would be good and useful for them tries to do it anyway and keeps failing.

"i can't stick with it"
"i can't stay consistent"
"i procrastinate a lot"
"i understand it's important but i can't get myself to do it"

an addict is helplessly trying to understand how his addiction is harmful, so he can finally drop it. the latter is trying to understand how his apathy is warranted even after knowing something is useful.

the only brilliant advice i've heard in the matter ‚Äî and also experienced it often, firsthand ‚Äî is master osho's:

if you're addicted to smoking, smoke more. smoke till you can't.

if you're procrastinating, procrastinate till you can't.

this works. if you're really addicted to something, do it till you either have such a terrible time, you naturally never go back to it again, or you get disillusioned/bored.

all you need is a visceral experience of the harm.

for example, let's say i make good money in a job where i'm not interested in the work at all. so i'm often procrastinating, till i can't. and what keeps me going is the fear of losing that income, not a love for the work itself.

and i realize this truth only when i stop convincing myself of how much i love the work and simply choose to do what i feel like, till the real fear grips me and i'm moved to act. only then i know what really drives me, which is not the work, but the money.

when you say "i should exercise" but don't, the stakes are simply not that high. but if you were to fully experience the consequences of not exercising in a high stakes situation ‚Äî say your gf getting the ick because you got winded during sex ‚Äî your motivation will now be intrinsic, and you will exercise.

so it's rarely about the thing itself, and usually about what that thing gets you. unless you know this, you won't be able to calculate the real trade-offs. so nothing about your behaviour will change.

if your behaviour isn't changing, it's also quite likely that you're okay with the trade-offs because a lot of them haven't manifested yet. with a smoking addiction, the real trade-offs only manifest once you're diagnosed with lung cancer. before that, you know it intellectually, but you don't KNOW it.

here's a simple insight i apply in my own life:

if i say i "understand" something or understand how important it is or how harmful it is, but it still doesn't do anything to change my behaviour, i do not understand it.

so the only thing you can do is wait for a calamity that makes you understand it on a visceral level. that's how most of us learn, ultimately.

i have very strong views on this because of one overarching principle:

an excellent measure of success is how little you have to compete ‚Äî both externally and internally.

people take statements like "combination of skills" and "t-shaped skillset" to buy time and delay doing the hard thing. the hard thing here being chasing depth and fleshing out the vertical in that "T" shape (which is ultimately rooted in self-awareness).

they serve as a comforting lie. you can always justify being average at multiple things by saying you're building a unique combination.

but years pass, and suddenly you realize you're still fighting for every opportunity, still competing with everyone else, still having to prove yourself ‚Äì just like day one.

very few generalists actually find their edge at some unique intersection of skills that's generally valuable in the market. most just drift along, collecting surface-level knowledge and wondering why they're still replaceable after years of "diverse experience."

yes, specialists can plateau too. often harder than generalists. but they know it, they chose it, and most importantly ‚Äì they rarely face intense competition. and just this privilege of not having to constantly compete is worth half your lifetime earnings. the psychological stability of being known for doing one thing exceptionally well can add many years to your life.

the secret to always being employed, no matter what the job market looks like:

be really good at something widely useful. it decouples/buffers you from the effects of supply and demand.

this a function of

liquidity of your skill x competence

a "liquid" skill is one that's transferable across industries, roles, and market conditions. the liquidity comes from how easily you can redeploy that skill in different contexts.

be too competent at a highly illiquid skill and you risk obsolescence. like being the world's best horse-cart racer in 2024. you might be incredibly skilled, but there's no demand.

have a highly liquid skill but average competence and you will be quickly pushed out of the market when demand wanes. like being an average web developer. it's a highly liquid skill, but in tough times, you're competing with thousands of others just like you. when companies cut jobs, being average makes you replaceable.

but when you have a highly liquid skill and high competence, you start decoupling from market forces. that's where you want to be.

you can

- command premium rates even in down markets
- quickly pivot to adjacent opportunities
- create your own demand through reputation

the worst is being average at something unimportant ‚Äî like being a mediocre chef serving some obscure cuisine. you're neither the best, nor useful across a wide-range of contexts.

"Man is a rope stretched between the animal and the Superman ‚Äî a rope over an abyss.

A dangerous crossing, a dangerous wayfaring, a dangerous looking-back, a dangerous trembling and halting.

What is great in man is that he is a bridge and not a goal: what is lovable in man is that he is an OVER-GOING and a DOWN-GOING.

I love those that know not how to live except as down-goers, for they are the over-goers.

I love the great despisers, because they are the great adorers, and arrows of longing for the other shore.

I love those who do not first seek a reason beyond the stars for going down and being sacrifices, but sacrifice themselves to the earth, that the earth of the Superman may hereafter arrive.

I love him who lives in order to know, and seeks to know in order that the Superman may hereafter live. Thus seeks he his own down-going.

I love him who labors and invents, that he may build the house for the Superman, and prepare for him earth, animal, and plant: for thus seeks he his own down-going.

I love him who loves his virtue: for virtue is the will to down-going, and an arrow of longing.

I love him who reserves no share of spirit for himself, but wants to be wholly the spirit of his virtue: thus walks he as spirit over the bridge.

I love him who makes his virtue his inclination and destiny: thus, for the sake of his virtue, he is willing to live on, or live no more.

I love him who desires not too many virtues. One virtue is more of a virtue than two, because it is more of a knot for one's destiny to cling to.

I love him whose soul is lavish, who wants no thanks and does not give back: for he always bestows, and desires not to keep for himself.

I love him who is ashamed when the dice fall in his favor, and who then asks: "Am I a dishonest player?" ‚Äî for he is willing to succumb.

I love him who scatters golden words in advance of his deeds, and always does more than he promises: for he seeks his own down-going.

I love him who justifies the future ones, and redeems the past ones: for he is willing to succumb through the present ones.

I love him who chastens his God, because he loves his God: for he must succumb through the wrath of his God.

I love him whose soul is deep even in the wounding, and may succumb through a small matter: thus goes he willingly over the bridge.

I love him whose soul is so overfull that he forgets himself, and all things that are in him: thus all things become his down-going.

I love him who is of a free spirit and a free heart: thus is his head only the bowels of his heart; his heart, however, causes his down-going.

I love all who are like heavy drops falling one by one out of the dark cloud that lowers over man: they herald the coming of the lightning, and succumb as heralds.

this is not to say that anyone else can have my precise vantage or have as much context as i do. i and i alone will have all the context at all times, because only i am privy to my real intent.

however, acknowledging that i alone possess the full context isn't a justification for judgment, but rather the very reason judgment becomes impossible. the exclusive nature of my vantage doesn't empower me to judge; it disqualifies me.

so, the only moments of true seeing come through conflict ‚Äî when my carefully constructed self-understanding meets resistance... not through my internal narrative or rationalization, but through my immediate, unpremeditated response. 

do i defend or say it like it is? the answer reveals everything.

this is why masters never judge: they understand that another's complete context is forever inaccessible. instead, they simply ask questions. the way someone responds tells the whole story, far more than any explanation they might give.

they create the space for truth to reveal itself through response. the question becomes a mirror, and the response shows what needs to be shown.

whether the seeker accepts or rejects what he sees depends on his sincerity alone.

truthseeking ends up in paradox. and once paradox is encountered, context becomes everything. 

yet context itself can become a trap. since much of my context is internal, i can easily delude myself into thinking that my view must be right simply because no other person inhabits my precise vantage. 

if i'm the only one with all the context at all times, i can justify anything.

this is one of the most subtle and dangerous forms of self-deception, precisely because it's where fear and self-interest masquerade as deep wisdom. the very recognition of context's all-pervading importance will lead to a new kind of dogmatism if you aren't careful.

this ‚Äî being a clear mirror unto thyself ‚Äî is the real work involved in meditation. and it never ends. its only destination is absolute confusion. and absolute confusion is freedom from the known.

indisciplined people attribute their success to luck way more than their disciplined peers. and the problem primarily has to do with how we define discipline and luck.

if you're someone others might call "indisciplined," you're likelier to chalk up your wins to luck. meanwhile, if you fit the "disciplined" mold, you might rarely credit luck at all. 

this says more about our collective biases than it does about how success actually works.

you might be getting things done in ways that work perfectly for you, but because they don't match what we're taught discipline should look like ‚Äî all those rigid schedules and visible struggle ‚Äî you discount your own effective patterns. 

when success comes, you might think "i just got lucky" because you weren't "really trying" in the way we are told we should.

but if you're the type who checks all the discipline boxes, you might push through and achieve some success even when you're focusing on the wrong things. 

and because you've put in all this visible effort that matches what we think discipline should look like, you'll probably resist seeing any role luck might have played.

you're so caught up in what we think discipline should look like that you miss what actually works. 

your effectiveness doesn't need to wear the costume you expect it to.

this works partly because 'learning' as a concept is often too vague and lacks structure. pure learning has no concrete outputs or feedback loops to validate progress. in contrast, actively doing something provides clear markers of success and naturally reinforces what works. this creates positive momentum.

this hands-on approach often feels unsatisfying to the learner. we want to clearly define and catalogue the concepts we're mastering. 

but real-world practice is messy; different skills and knowledge combine in incomplete ways. so, while it produces good results, the chaotic nature of "doing the thing" itself feels uncomfortable and disorganized.

the classic difference between an academic mindset and a doer mindset. academics wanna "learn" as a goal in itself, while most of us would be better off treating it as a means to an end and nothing more. so all the studying that has to happen will happen as a part of doing the thing and not as a separate end in itself.

learning is clean and simple; real world application is messy and complex.

a question i find myself asking quite often these days: 

would I have come up with this idea, habit, or way of living on my own? or did I just read it somewhere (or was inducted into some established order) and hence made it part of my life?

sometimes i know i wouldn't have ‚Äî which means I don't really understand it firsthand. i have no authority on it. i've merely accepted a way of life i do not understand and have never questioned.*

and sometimes, the answer is "yes, i was living with that idea all along and and reading about it just put words to what I already knew."

there are ideas that feel like they were downloaded versus those that were already living inside us, just waiting for the right words to crystallize them.

knowing which is which is a big part of really knowing yourself.

and it's almost unsettling when you start doing this audit of your own beliefs and behaviors and realize how many of them you've just... absorbed.

like, you might have strong opinions about how to structure your day or how many times to eat in a day or what constitutes "success" or even what makes you happy ‚Äî but how much of that is actually from your own lived experience versus what you've internalized from books, social media, or just ambient cultural pressure?

it is rare to truly arrive at something through pure observation and experimentation. but only that is real authority. everything else is second-hand goods that are not yours.

*seeing this also rids me of the (unchallenged) necessity of believing in something or doing that thing. in that moment, i lose that part of my natural conditioning. that's one constraint/rule taken away from my rule book. i'm now a freer human being because i realise my lack of authority on it.

podcasts solve for both demand and supply side incentives at once:

1. they're high alpha: stuff you hear in a good podcast you won't find documented anywhere else. so they have high entertainment value

2. conversations are a great way to reveal experiences and domain insights you'd never have fleshed out or articulated otherwise, so they're valuable even for the guests, not just for the hosts

3. they are vastly easier to produce than other long form content like books, or even video/text essays, because you're sourcing and leveraging content your guests already have

4. they're relatable: for once, people get to see your spontaneous and natural side, and not a carefully engineered or doctored one. they're able to see themselves in you once you stop being a purely digital persona and come out in the flesh

5. they require lower intellectual investment than a book and are more engaging to a wider base

6. they align with the incentives of the platforms  that are heavily pushing video because it increases time spent on the platform

and some more reasons i can't recall right now

there is an interesting question here, btw. 

i was with a friend in delhi not that long ago. and there, we saw a BMW SUV in front of us in the traffic. and i asked him if he knew how expensive it was.

"3 cr."

"i wonder why someone would spend that amount of money on a car. i personally wouldn't spend that much on a car even if i had that kind of money"

"dekho baba, 3 cr ki gaadi hai matlab atleast 300 cr ka net worth toh hoga"

so, in his mind, someone would buy a car worth X if their net worth was at least 100x.

now, i don't think this multiple is constant or even scales linearly, because you quickly hit the limit on how expensive a car you can buy, as compared to how much wealth you can own.

(as long as you're not a person who buys diamond-studded iphones or gold lambos)

but, what i'm more interested in knowing is the perception. if I have a 10 lakh rupee car, how much would you assume my net worth is?

of course, most of it depends on your knowledge of what kind of person i am. if i'm really pragmatic and down-to-earth, my car would scarcely be a good proxy for my net worth. and if i'm really status-seeking, an expensive car would be one of the first things i buy when i start earning well. 

so the 100x multiple in the former would be more like a 1.5x - 2x multiple in the latter.
